meanings.definition: The act of bringing something to an end or conclusion.
meanings.sent1: The movie had a happy windup with all the loose ends tied up nicely.
meanings.sent2: The windup of the party was marked by a beautiful fireworks display.
meanings.sent3: The windup of the play left the audience feeling satisfied and content.
meanings.sent4: The windup of the story was unexpected, leaving everyone in awe.
meanings.sent5: The windup of the meeting was punctuated by a round of applause.

meanings.definition: A mechanism for tightening or winding a device.
meanings.sent1: The toy car's windup key was missing, so it couldn't move.
meanings.sent2: The old clock had a traditional windup mechanism that required daily winding.
meanings.sent3: The windup of the music box played a sweet melody that filled the room.
meanings.sent4: The windup of the watch was smooth and precise, ensuring accurate timekeeping.
meanings.sent5: The windup of the toy robot made it walk and light up with excitement.

meanings.sent1: She had to windup her presentation quickly due to time constraints.
meanings.sent2: He likes to windup his day by reading a bedtime story to his children.
meanings.sent3: Let's windup this game and see who the winner is!
meanings.sent4: I need to windup my work before I can join you for lunch.
meanings.sent5: The students were eager to windup the school year and start their summer break.

meanings.definition: To twist or coil something into a compact shape.
meanings.sent1: He had to windup the garden hose neatly to store it in the shed.
meanings.sent2: She would windup her hair into a bun before going to bed.
meanings.sent3: The magician would windup the rope into intricate knots for his trick.
meanings.sent4: The snake would windup its body before striking at its prey.
meanings.sent5: The gymnast would windup her body before executing a perfect somersault.
